questions.question: If matrix $A$ is $2 \times 3$ and matrix $B$ is $3 \times 4$, what are the dimensions of the product $AB$?
questions.explanation: The inner dimensions ($3$) match, so the product is defined. The outer dimensions ($2$ and $4$) determine the size of the resulting matrix.

questions.question: Which of the following matrix multiplications is undefined?
options: A $3 \times 2$ matrix multiplied by a $3 \times 2$ matrix.
A $1 \times 4$ matrix multiplied by a $4 \times 1$ matrix.
A $2 \times 2$ matrix multiplied by a $2 \times 5$ matrix.
A $5 \times 3$ matrix multiplied by a $3 \times 3$ matrix.
questions.explanation: For a $3 \times 2$ and a $3 \times 2$, the inner dimensions ($2$ and $3$) do not match. You cannot multiply them.

questions.question: Is matrix multiplication commutative? (Does $AB = BA$?)
options: No, order generally matters in matrix multiplication.
Yes, it follows the same rules as real number multiplication.
Yes, but only for square matrices.
questions.explanation: Matrix multiplication is non-commutative. Even if both $AB$ and $BA$ are defined, they rarely result in the same matrix.

questions.question: Calculate the first element (Row 1, Column 1) of $AB$ if $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}$.
questions.explanation: Multiply Row 1 of $A$ by Column 1 of $B$: $(1 \times 5) + (2 \times 7) = 5 + 14 = 19$.

questions.question: If you multiply a $4 \times 2$ matrix by a $2 \times 1$ matrix, how many elements will the resulting matrix have?
questions.explanation: The result is a $4 \times 1$ matrix, which contains exactly $4$ elements.

questions.question: What is the result of multiplying any square matrix $A$ by the Identity matrix $I$?
questions.explanation: The Identity matrix acts like the number $1$ in scalar multiplication; $AI = IA = A$.

questions.question: Find $AB$ for $A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}$.
questions.explanation: This is a $1 \times 2$ times a $2 \times 1$, resulting in a $1 \times 1$. $(2 \times 3) + (0 \times 4) = 6$.

questions.question: When computing the element in the second row and third column of a product matrix, which parts of the original matrices are used?
options: Row $2$ of the first matrix and Column $3$ of the second matrix.
Column $2$ of the first matrix and Row $3$ of the second matrix.
Row $3$ of the first matrix and Column $2$ of the second matrix.
questions.explanation: The position $(i, j)$ in the product is the dot product of Row $i$ from the first matrix and Column $j$ from the second.

questions.question: What happens to the dimensions of the result if you multiply an $n \times n$ matrix by another $n \times n$ matrix?
questions.explanation: Multiplying two square matrices of the same size always results in another square matrix of that same size.

questions.question: Calculate $\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}$.
questions.explanation: Row 1: $(0 \times x) + (1 \times y) = y$. Row 2: $(1 \times x) + (0 \times y) = x$. This matrix effectively swaps the variables.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the row-by-column method.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Remember: Rows of the first, Columns of the second.
scoreMessages.50: Practice the dot product calculation for each element in the result.
scoreMessages.0: Review the dimension rules for matrix multiplication before attempting more problems.
